awd_titl_txt: Broadening Participation in STEM Faculty: A Program to support the Diversity Initiative for Tenure in Economics (DITE)
awd_abstract_narration:
Minorities are seriously under-represented in tenured economics faculty positions in US universities resulting in lack of role models for young under-represented groups.  This lack of racial and ethnic diversity hampers the creation of a diversified STEM workforce and also lead to lack of diversity in research topics in economics. Broadening Participation in STEM Faculty: A Program to Support the Diversity Initiative for Tenure in Economics (DITE) is a program to  support under-represented junior faculty in economics. The broad goal of the program is to increase the number of faculty from under-represented populations in economics who hold tenured positions in the academy generally. The project will also focus on increasing tenured faculty in economics at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) and Hispanic Serving Colleges and Universities (HSCUs). DITE fellows will be mentored by distinguished professors of economics in integrating research projects, establishing a credible research portfolio and publishing and service record that will get them tenured in economic departments.  DITE will support a yearly cohort of 15 junior economics faculty over the two-year span of this proposed grant (for a cumulative total of up to 30).  DITE fellows who obtain tenure are expected to mentor your economic faculty of color.  By helping to diversify the economics faculty in the US, the proposed activity will help to create a diversified STEM workforce and research agenda for the 21st century, thus strengthening the US economy. 

Broadening Participation in STEM Faculty:  Broadening Participation in STEM Faculty: A Program to Support the Diversity Initiative for Tenure in Economics (DITE) is a program to  support under-represented junior faculty in the economics profession.  The continued gross under-representation of economists from racial minorities and ethnic groups in the ranks of college and university faculty creates an imperative for special efforts to change the STEM field and the academy through increased presence of under-represented groups (URM). Serious under-representation does not only inhibit US?s ability to create a diversified STEM workforce for the 21st century and beyond, it also skews economic research away from issues that may concern to these under-represented groups.  Because there are so few URM professors of economics, there is a greater cost to society when any single one of these professors is lost in the tenure pipeline. The DITE curriculum is designed to help URM faculty of economics decode the academy, demystify the promotion and tenure process, and identify, develop, and leverage a research program to a tenure position.  The DITE program will therefore benefit the US through a diversified economics faculty and an enhanced research portfolio.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Diversity Initiative for Tenure in Economics (DITE) Program was established in 2008 under the direction of William Darity, Jr. Professor of Public Policy and Economics at Duke University. Its mission is to facilitate successful transition from junior faculty to tenured positions within the academy. Although DITE is open to all groups, it has a primary focus on those designated as underrepresented in the field of economics. Over the past 15 years, there have been 134 fellows, 11 are full professors out of whom three hold distinguished professorships and 36 are associate professors. There were 84 fellows in the cohorts prior to 2017, the cohorts anticipated to yield the largest number of tenured faculty members since virtually all of the fellows participated in DITE within the first three years after receipt of the Ph.D. Out of those 84, 10 are full professors, including the three distinguished professors, and 32 are associate professors. There are more than 40 papers published in refereed journals written jointly by fellows and mentors since the point at which each were participants in DITE. In 2021 DITE fellow Isaiah Andrews was awarded the John Bates Clark Medal (given by the American Economics Association to the top economist under 40). In 2022,  DITE fellow Lisa Cook is the first African American woman to serve on the Federal Reserve Board of Governors.
